Early Access Review
								This is one of the times that I with there was some another option other than yes or no when it came to recommending this game.  I personally like the IDEA of the gameplay and the concept, but I wouldn't go so far as to say that I love the general gameplay as it stands right now either.  Hopefully that'll make more sense as you continue to read my review, but let's get down to it.In terms of graphics, it actually looks pretty decent for an indie game.  I've seen some people saying that their computers couldn't handle it...but I've got a Nvidia Geforce 610 GT and I managed to run the game with just about everything on whilst also getting some pretty decent frames, so seeing as how this is a 'work in progress' I'm sure that subject to change...for the good or otherwise.  When it comes to the camera effects and the SFX and whatnot, I'd say that's mostly where the game shines at in terms of graphics.  The distortions are done pretty well, there's some haze if you try to look at something in the distance, and the colors even begin to seperate when it rains (I.E. the water causes the camera to see Red, Green, and Blue).  Now, all this being said, there are some flaws here and there.  Some examples would be some textures looking...a bit outdated/out of place, randomly changing pictures (And not in the good way either...as in the paintings seem to be actually changing into something completely different before my eyes at times.  If that's part of the game, then just shoot me a message, but I'm pretty sure I saw one of those Michael Jackson paintings literally morph into one of the bathroom paintings.) There are some things that I did kinda gripe about in the game that others might say was just me nitpicking, but personally they kinda stood out a lot.  For one thing the perspective of your character is...odd.  I feel like he's taller than the viewpoint may imply, as referenced by the furniture and whatnot, but whenever I attempted to interact with something I couldn't help but feel like I was incredibly short.  The rooms could have been a bit more interesting in my opinion, and the design of the house just felt...off.  Now the sound is one of the high points.  Listening to the game via my computer speakers doesn't do it enough justice, so I normally use my headphones when I play this game.  It does a fair job of immersing you into the game via sound, and it does help to make the game more atmospheric/scary.When it comes to gameplay, the premise of the game is pretty basic.  You go around the house and record the strange occurances that happen there, or don't happen as the case may be.  You've got your flashlight, and you've also actually got a time limit on how long you can stay up before you have to charge your camera.  If you don't make it back to your bedroom before the battery hits zero then you die.  You can go around the house and collect/read the letters left behind by the previous owner, as well as learn the history of the house via the laptop, or you can learn about our main character's background.  The story is nothing special at all.  It's actually your typical 'Haunted House' type plot.  I understand that the game is supposed to be, more or less, of an homage to Paranormal Activity, but the story could really have been a bit less cliched in my opinion.  Not that you're required to even figure out the story, as you could just play the game without ever picking up a single note.  The scares aren't very scary.  I jumped due to...well, jump-scares, but that's it.  I never felt real-deal fear while I played the game, and some of the scares just felt a bit forced and really typical for me.  I get that they're dynamic to help make the game stay fresh, but that only works if the game continues to scare you...that never really happened for me.This isn't going to affect my decision on how I'd rate this game, but if you came here with the expectation that the game would have fairly frequent updates...well, then you may want to look elsewhere.  As you could probably tell from the patch-notes about, the game hasn't been updated since April.  I don't currently know what the creator is doing as of right now, but I had heard that he has tried to fund the project through a website other than Kickstarter.  I currently don't know the name.Personally, I don't know if I'd recommend this game as it stands.  I liked the idea/concept of this game, and I'd very much like to see how much farther it'll go during development, but as it stands it's just an alright game to me.  It offers nothing new in the way of gameplay, story, or otherwise, but at the same time the premise of the game is pretty appealing to those who like to try out new things.***EDIT*** 7/1/15So I've checked this game every chance that I've gotten since the latest update on New Year's Eve, and...nothing.  No updates, no latest news, nothing.  As I've stated before, it's not a bad game and it shows promise...but what's the point of promise if it just doesn't deliver?Seriously, I've just about given up on the game at this point.  I could seriously care less about the game being converted to UE4.  Why not finish the UE3 version of the game first and work on the UE4 version second?  It'd certainly give us all something to do.

Early Access Review
								I'm a horror movie and game fanatic and keep trying to find good horror games that aren't simply "jump-scare" filled, but gradual building, easy-paced to make the progression of terror all the more effective. Paranormal was thankfully one of these games. I thoroughly appreciated how the haunting changed in sequence each time -even though there were several things I saw on a regular basis in most outcomes and very few times there were outcomes that never happened to me again. The environment and interaction is immersive, beautiful, and definitely eerie, making one feel progressively helpless, even if you begin to learn more about what you are being haunted by. Kinda sad ultimate ending (in the basement), not sure how many "final"/"true" endings there are, but it was still good. Controls were easy and comfortable, some discoveries were repetitive but still rewarding (as you didn't know what the next event would be) and the mannequin in the picture on the wall that got closer each time still continued to disturb me, no matter how many times I saw it. Very well done game -I hope to find more like it.

Early Access Review
								After the death of his dog, young Mattel Clark has decided to investigate his house to capture the paranormal events that have been occurring. The artist may have gotten more than he bargained for...With that creepy tagline out of the way, let's talk turkey here. Paranormal is a game inspired by the likes of The Blair Witch Project, Paranormal Activity, and Cloverfield. What it does is provide you with a startling haunted house-type simulator that offers jump scares and slowly simmering fear with a basic, perhaps shallow storyline that can vary in your playlength.My tips for best game play? Always play unabridged. You'll get more scares that way. I still haven't experienced every scare yet and as of now, I'm starting to become too paranoid to experience them all. Collecting all of the collectibles is also a near impossible feat and you will get a visit from the succubus if you are attempting it.Pros:- Offers varied scares- Game length can be short or long depending on your choices in game- Replayability- Bare bones storyline leaving you to investigate for clues- Developer is rebuilding the game and is active in sharing what's next for ParanormalCons:- Not your prettiest game- Storyline could use a little more structure- House layout can be confusing- There is no saveI don't scare easily and I'm not a fan of the "camera footage horror" film genres, but I did find the game enjoyable. If you're looking for combat or zombies, that's not here. You're at the mercy of the hauntings here and you're just recording it. There aren't any puzzles. You just walk around and watch the haunted house come to life. If you just want to be a little scared, this is probably the game for you.

Early Access Review
								Paranormal - One of the greatest edge-of-your-seat horror games I have played. It's up there with Outlast. Paranormal takes on the elements and features (sounds, effects, visuals) as the Paranormal movie trilogy. It's your Blair Witch Project type of set up - found footage, you know the type. The plot is simple, you document paranormal activity in a house and try avoid being killed by enviromental and accidental mistakes. For isntance: You have to sleep to recharge your camera's battery. If you run out of juice before you get to bed, you will probably end up dead. The game also uses sound efx to set a scary atmosphere. Footsteps, doors closing, items breaking, shouting, crying, etc. Plus we cant leave out the roaring sound when something "paranormal" is about to happen. As for replayability, each experience is different. Objects are located in different places, things happen in some play throughs and don't in others. Over all, if your looking for a good scary game like slenderman or outlast, this is a good game to add to your horror game collection.

								I tried to capture the paranormal on my camcorder and all I got was 30 minutes of buyers remorse.The game has always claimed to never play the same way twice, and yet I have yet to see a single playthrough that wasn't a complete silhouette of my first. From the very first minutes of the very first day you can find levitating or moving objects, tryhard creepy posing-doll figures, and a whole bunch of hollow trope appearances. It really feels like the game is constantly rolling an RNG and randomly fires off a 'spooky' happening from a small list, and by the time your preset death occurs you will have likely seen the whole list. Some of the startle-scares try so hard that it actually becomes laughable, one of which is literally just a posing-doll ornament that just slides in under your view like a motion-tween HUD element, and then slides away again, without explanation or reaction from the character. Yeah. It's that kind of game.I would have ADORED a game of genuine paranormal exposure and investigation in an enclosed space, but this is not that game it claims to be. I'm pretty sure the only kind of person that would enjoy this game is the kind of person that thinks a 'screamer' is 'horror'. Worse yet that a kickstarter was put up for a second area (yes, a second zone, in the first game) before the first area was even finished, and OH LOOK, it's STILL in early access!Save your money. 								There are ways that you could spend your time that are much worse than playing Paranormal. It's a fairly good indie game, and it's pretty challenging to figure out each puzzle. You always have X amount of time to figure certain things out. The scares are good, the soundtrack is some great dark ambient music that I wouldn't mind just having on a disk, and the letters you find are pretty interesting. The graphics, even for an indie game using the Unreal engine, are a bit dated. I don't know how long this game has been in development, but the overall layout for the game is basically one map, if you remember the heyday of playing Unreal Tournament in the "Giant room" maps - it comes across a lot like that, though a bit less cartoony. The use of wooden figures throughout the game is done pretty well, too - as someone who has used these to do different poses in order to gain a certain degree of perspective from different angles, I have thought more than once about the creepy factor that they represent. Their utility in this game is as a tool to make you creeped-out. That seems to be the focus here, a skin-crawling feeling that is drawn out, less of a jump scare horror game. It plays out like you would expect a haunting to play out, if you believe in that sort of thing. This is one of those horror games that in order to become immersed, you really should turn out the lights and make things as dark as possible. The game's pacing is also almost unbearably slow, but that's a common complaint for almost any game in this genre. In short: Not bad. 6/10 - The price gets a point knocked off. I'm not saying it's a regretable purchase, I'm just saying it's a bit expensive for what it is. If you can obtain the game in a bundle, do so, you will be doing yourself a favor.

Early Access Review
								In 'Paranormal' you play as an artist who has rented their own personal studio where they can work on their art without being disturbed. But then you start to notice you may not be alone in the studio, no one believes you, so you decide to try and collect 'evidence'.You don't actually collect evidence, but the developer uses it as an excuse to make your point of view through a fuzzy, crappy, pixelated video recorder that no one should have any business owning in 2015.The entire game involves you wandering around your studio, trying to find proof the house is haunted. As you spend more time in the studio, you'll find little tidbits of information that help you slowly understand the haunting and the story behind it.The studio is crampt and small, making exploring the house a very short affair. What is supposed to attract you is all of the paranormal activity happening in the studio. The game boasts re-play-ability by having 'randomly generated' events happen. The issue is, after the first or second play through, there isn't really anything random about it, the events that happen are so few and varied you may very well start seeing the same thing happen during the first play through.Obviously, since this game is in Early Access, it's unpolished. But I wouldn't even use that word with this title. The last time I played it, the game had parts of game play elements that were scrapped, but never removed, the game had two title screens, one of which doesn't work or save any of your options properly.If you want to believe what the author says on the game's forums here, you'd be lead to believe not only has he fixed several bugs, added in new content and added in a demo for the Unreal Engine 4 remake, but I didn't see any of that. Why? Because right after the title screen the game locks up every, single time. This isn't an issue of my hardware, I got a great set-up that plays current gen titles just fine. The issue is with the developer, his programming and his progress with the title. At this point, I just consider this lost money. If the author reads this, I wouldn't mind you buying a game for me from my wish list to make up for the worthless garbage you sold me.
